questions.question: When scaling the C.R.A.D.L.E. Framework™ from 1-on-1 coaching to a group dynamic, what is the most critical shift the facilitator must make?
options: Moving from a directive 'expert' role to a facilitative 'guide' role that encourages peer-to-peer learning
Increasing the length of the curriculum to ensure all individual questions are answered
Eliminating the 'Emotional Integration' phase to save time for clinical skills
Standardizing all birth preferences to a single template for the entire group
questions.explanation: Scaling requires shifting from being the sole source of information to facilitating a community where participants learn from both the coach and each other, leveraging group synergy.

questions.question: According to the 'Curriculum Architecture' lesson, the 5E Instructional Model is used to sequence workshops. What does the 'Elaborate' phase involve?
options: The initial hook to get parents interested in the topic
A formal lecture using PowerPoint slides
Applying learned concepts to new, more complex scenarios like a simulated 'stalled labor'
The final quiz at the end of the workshop
questions.explanation: The 'Elaborate' phase challenges students to apply their knowledge to new situations, deepening their understanding and skill mastery beyond basic memorization.

questions.question: When facilitating hands-on skills like the 'Double Hip Squeeze' in a group setting, which technique ensures safety and competency across all participants?
options: The 'Watch One, Do One, Teach One' methodology with instructor 'spot-checking'
Only allowing participants to practice on mannequins to avoid injury
Showing a high-definition video and skipping the physical practice
Directing all participants to perform the skill simultaneously without supervision
questions.explanation: The 'Watch One, Do One, Teach One' method is the gold standard for tactile skill acquisition, ensuring participants can perform and explain the technique safely.

questions.question: In the Virtual Tech Stack lesson, what is identified as the 'Engagement Anchor' for online workshops?
options: High-quality 4K video resolution
Strategic use of breakout rooms for intimate, small-group processing
Automated email reminders sent 15 minutes before the start
The use of virtual backgrounds to hide the instructor's home office
questions.explanation: Breakout rooms are essential in virtual settings to combat 'Zoom fatigue' and recreate the intimacy and safety of an in-person circle.

questions.question: When proposing a Clinical Partnership to a hospital, which data point is most likely to secure 'Integrated Program' status?
options: The number of 'likes' on the program's Instagram page
A reduction in non-medically indicated cesarean rates among program participants
The aesthetic quality of the workshop materials
The total number of years the doula coach has been in practice
questions.explanation: Hospitals and clinical providers prioritize 'Hard Data' and clinical outcomes, such as reduced intervention rates and improved patient satisfaction scores.

questions.question: In the 'Postpartum Circle' lesson, what is the primary objective of 'Emotional Integration'?
options: Teaching parents how to sleep-train their infants within the first week
Reconciling the 'Idealized Birth' with the 'Actual Birth' to prevent birth trauma from taking root
Providing a marketplace for participants to sell used baby gear
Focusing exclusively on the physical recovery of the birthing person
questions.explanation: Emotional Integration helps parents process their birth story, aligning their expectations with reality to promote psychological healing and confidence.

questions.question: A Net Promoter Score (NPS) is a key metric in Data-Driven Optimization. What NPS score is considered 'World-Class' in the doula coaching industry?
options: 70 or above
Exactly 100
questions.explanation: An NPS of 70 or above is considered world-class, indicating that the vast majority of participants are 'promoters' who will actively refer others to the program.

questions.question: When marketing a Signature Group Program, what is the purpose of the 'Waitlist Strategy'?
options: To make people feel bad for not signing up sooner
To gather data on potential interest and build 'Social Proof' before the official cart opens
To avoid having to build a website
To limit the number of participants to only two people
questions.explanation: A waitlist strategy builds anticipation, validates demand, and allows for targeted marketing to a warm audience, increasing conversion rates during the launch.

questions.question: A participant in your workshop is sharing a traumatic experience that is beginning to 'trigger' other group members. What is the most professional facilitative response?
options: Tell the participant to stop talking immediately
The 'Acknowledge, Pause, and Pivot' technique—validating the speaker while gently moving to a grounding exercise
Ignore the situation and continue with the PowerPoint presentation
Join in the emotional sharing to show you are also vulnerable
questions.explanation: The 'Acknowledge, Pause, and Pivot' technique maintains the safety of the container for all participants while respecting the individual's experience.

questions.question: Which 'Curriculum Pillar' ensures that a group program is accessible to participants with different learning needs (visual, auditory, kinesthetic)?
options: Universal Design for Learning (UDL)
The Financial Sustainability Pillar
The Tech-First Pillar
The Clinical Compliance Pillar
questions.explanation: Universal Design for Learning (UDL) is a framework to improve and optimize teaching and learning for all people based on scientific insights into how humans learn.
